Executive Order Puts America First in Global Environmental Pacts

Overview: This executive order prioritizes American jobs and industries over international environmental agreements. It may lead to U.S. withdrawal from such pacts, reducing obligations but impacting university research funding and global partnerships.

Bottom Line: Universities should prepare for potential funding cuts and increased costs related to sustainability research and initiatives.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Research Funding: Reduced federal funding for sustainability and climate research

Operational Costs: Increased expenses for energy efficiency and emissions reduction efforts

Global Partnerships: Strained relationships with international institutions and researchers

Important Dates:

  • 06/01/2025: Expected release of detailed implementation guidelines from EPA
  • 09/30/2025: Deadline to submit feedback on proposed rules

Affected Departments:

Office of Research, Finance & Administration, Facilities Management, Office of Sustainability

Action Plan:

Action Required: Yes - Assess research portfolio and budget for areas dependent on international environmental agreements.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Inventory all research projects and grants tied to international environmental agreements
  • Identify any sustainability initiatives or commitments made under such agreements
  • Estimate financial and operational impact of potential U.S. withdrawal from agreements

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Develop contingency plans for affected research projects and partnerships
  • Reassess budget priorities to account for anticipated funding changes

Long-term Considerations:

  • Evaluate overall approach to sustainability in light of changing federal policies
  • Explore alternative funding sources and partnership models for affected areas

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: Likely need to reassign or hire personnel to assess policy impacts across different areas

Budget: May require reallocation of funds to cover increased operational costs and bridge funding gaps

Technology: Minimal new technology needs anticipated

External Expertise: Engage outside experts to help interpret and respond to changing federal mandates
